alert.note: Alert for San Luis Obispo (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued March 28 at 5:52AM PDT by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 730 AM PDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding due to moderate to locally heavy rainfall has bee extended. * WHERE...A portion of southwest California, including San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara, and including the Alisal burn area. * WHEN...Until 730 AM PDT. * IMPACTS...Heavy rainfall could trigger shallow debris flows in and near the Alisal burn area. Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Rises in small streams and normally dry arroyos. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 547 AM PDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges continues to indicate moderate to locally heavy rainfall with a band of rain moving through San Luis Obispo and western Santa Barbara Counties. Rainfall rates with this band have been observed to be between 0.33 and 0.66 inch per hour. Locally higher rainfall amounts are possible along the south coast of Santa Barbara County. This will cause urban and small stream flooding and could cause minor mud and debris flow from the Alisal burn area. Overflowing poor drainage areas will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Santa Maria, San Luis Obispo, Lompoc, Paso Robles, Morro Bay, Pismo Beach, Santa Ynez, Point Conception, Atascadero, Arroyo Grande, Nipomo, Cambria, Solvang, Gaviota State Park, Refugio State Beach, El Capitan State Beach and Grover Beach. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
